item.title: CodeUSA - 317
item.dc:creator: @Codeusa12 Codeusa12
item.description:
@Codeusa12 wrote:

[quote=“sinisoul, post:53, topic:418466”]Sorry for not posting a update log, I have an engagement down in the city today so I was busy last night being ‘unproductive’ and what not. Anyway, as we progress further into finishing the cache editor GUI I want to make a shout out to Andrew and thank him for all his support and dealing with my bickering. Without you, I may have never tried to finish this project.

October 22 -

My focus in the past two days has been -as I stated before my post was ruined because of the splash screen incident- design. The entire idea revolving around the cache editing GUI is not to hard code everything in, but rather develop two libraries that are side by side and minimize the amount of compiled code. Although I do not expect to do everything in Java, the only things I have found useful in Java are the concurrency, networking and swing packages. Although all do their job well, the entire point of what I want to eventually get to is a plugin based system for just about everything where each plugin is treated independent. Although the availability to bridge variables in plugins will be available, I will be suggesting that it shouldn’t be. These features where they are not stand alone, might just be done in Java. I have yet to further map it out.

The final product for building the frame was completed today, although I will need to invest some time into investigating how I will do action listeners.

--[[ buildframe.lua
    	Written by Hadyn Fitzgerald
]]

--Bind the toolkit 
dofile("./bin/scripts/bind/bindtoolkit.lua")

--Create the frame table
local Frame = {}

--Create the constructor function
function Frame.new()

	--Create the local table
	local self = {}
	
	--Private Variables:
	local f = luajava.newInstance("java.awt.Frame")
	local m = dofile("./bin/scripts/app/frame/menu/buildmenubar.lua")
	
	--Attach the menu to the frame
	m:attachTo(f)
	f:setSize(500, 500)
	
	--Get the menu bar for this frame
	function self:getMenuBar() 
		return m
	end
	
	--Set the icon of this frame
	function self:setIcon(icon)
		f:setIconImage(icon)
	end
	
	--Sets this frame visible or not visible
	function self:setVisible(bool)
		f:setVisible(bool)
	end
	
	return self
end

--Create a new frame
frame = Frame.new()

--Load the frame icon
local icon = toolkit:getDefaultToolkit():getImage("./media/icon.png") or nil

--Set the icon for the frame if needed
if icon ~= nil then
	frame:setIcon(icon)
end

frame:getMenuBar():addMenu("File"):addMenu("Sub"):addMenu("Sub"):addMenuItem("Finally")
frame:getMenuBar():addMenu("File"):addMenu("Sub"):addMenu("Su"):addMenuItem("Finally")
frame:getMenuBar():addMenu("Edit"):addMenuItem("Moparscape")

--Set the frame to visible
frame:setVisible(true)

return frame

As you can see from this, I encapsulated a frame and then added other supporting methods to help add or remove features. This is because I need to control the amount of features that a plugin developer has available to them, to help constrict and streamline the design process for creating plugins. In cases like this however, I may add some support to make sure a script such as this does not get called by outside sources unless they have specific permissions to do so. Creating a new frame such as this (minus the adding menu, setting the size, and making it visible) will be solely exclusive to this script just as the main backbone for the application. This is not a script to make new Frames as you could easily do that with the luajava.newInstance(“classname”, …params). This is to help support plugins and make their job a bit easier to add new menus and what not.

frame:getMenuBar():addMenu("File"):addMenu("Sub"):addMenu("Sub"):addMenuItem("Finally")
frame:getMenuBar():addMenu("File"):addMenu("Sub"):addMenu("Su"):addMenuItem("Finally")
frame:getMenuBar():addMenu("Edit"):addMenuItem("Moparscape")

One of the neat features that I am sad to report that I cannot show you, is the idea behind the tree system for menus. Since the idea of having two menus for a screen sounded fairly stupid, I just created a table for each ‘build’ script that had a table with the purpose of storing and checking what items were on a menu or menu bar.

I know development is slow guys, but from here on out as soon as the plugin API is finished thing will start picking up majorly. Thanks for reading this if you did, and have a great Saturday.[/quote]

October 22nd, Andrew is forced to learn LUA for the project.

Good job Sini, glad to have you.

Read full topic

item.title: CodeUSA - 317
item.dc:creator: @sinisoul sini
item.description:
@sinisoul wrote:

Sorry for not posting a update log, I have an engagement down in the city today so I was busy last night being ‘unproductive’ and what not. Anyway, as we progress further into finishing the cache editor GUI I want to make a shout out to Andrew and thank him for all his support and dealing with my bickering. Without you, I may have never tried to finish this project.

October 22 -

My focus in the past two days has been -as I stated before my post was ruined because of the splash screen incident- design. The entire idea revolving around the cache editing GUI is not to hard code everything in, but rather develop two libraries that are side by side and minimize the amount of compiled code. Although I do not expect to do everything in Java, the only things I have found useful in Java are the concurrency, networking and swing packages. Although all do their job well, the entire point of what I want to eventually get to is a plugin based system for just about everything where each plugin is treated independent. Although the availability to bridge variables in plugins will be available, I will be suggesting that it shouldn’t be. These features where they are not stand alone, might just be done in Java. I have yet to further map it out.

The final product for building the frame was completed today, although I will need to invest some time into investigating how I will do action listeners.

--[[ buildframe.lua
    	Written by Hadyn Fitzgerald
]]

--Bind the toolkit 
dofile("./bin/scripts/bind/bindtoolkit.lua")

--Create the frame table
local Frame = {}

--Create the constructor function
function Frame.new()

	--Create the local table
	local self = {}
	
	--Private Variables:
	local f = luajava.newInstance("java.awt.Frame")
	local m = dofile("./bin/scripts/app/frame/menu/buildmenubar.lua")
	
	--Attach the menu to the frame
	m:attachTo(f)
	f:setSize(500, 500)
	
	--Get the menu bar for this frame
	function self:getMenuBar() 
		return m
	end
	
	--Set the icon of this frame
	function self:setIcon(icon)
		f:setIconImage(icon)
	end
	
	--Sets this frame visible or not visible
	function self:setVisible(bool)
		f:setVisible(bool)
	end
	
	return self
end

--Create a new frame
frame = Frame.new()

--Load the frame icon
local icon = toolkit:getDefaultToolkit():getImage("./media/icon.png") or nil

--Set the icon for the frame if needed
if icon ~= nil then
	frame:setIcon(icon)
end

frame:getMenuBar():addMenu("File"):addMenu("Sub"):addMenu("Sub"):addMenuItem("Finally")
frame:getMenuBar():addMenu("File"):addMenu("Sub"):addMenu("Su"):addMenuItem("Finally")
frame:getMenuBar():addMenu("Edit"):addMenuItem("Moparscape")

--Set the frame to visible
frame:setVisible(true)

return frame

As you can see from this, I encapsulated a frame and then added other supporting methods to help add or remove features. This is because I need to control the amount of features that a plugin developer has available to them, to help constrict and streamline the design process for creating plugins. In cases like this however, I may add some support to make sure a script such as this does not get called by outside sources unless they have specific permissions to do so. Creating a new frame such as this (minus the adding menu, setting the size, and making it visible) will be solely exclusive to this script just as the main backbone for the application. This is not a script to make new Frames as you could easily do that with the luajava.newInstance(“classname”, …params). This is to help support plugins and make their job a bit easier to add new menus and what not.

frame:getMenuBar():addMenu("File"):addMenu("Sub"):addMenu("Sub"):addMenuItem("Finally")
frame:getMenuBar():addMenu("File"):addMenu("Sub"):addMenu("Su"):addMenuItem("Finally")
frame:getMenuBar():addMenu("Edit"):addMenuItem("Moparscape")

One of the neat features that I am sad to report that I cannot show you, is the idea behind the tree system for menus. Since the idea of having two menus for a screen sounded fairly stupid, I just created a table for each ‘build’ script that had a table with the purpose of storing and checking what items were on a menu or menu bar.

I know development is slow guys, but from here on out as soon as the plugin API is finished thing will start picking up majorly. Thanks for reading this if you did, and have a great Saturday.

item.title: CodeUSA - 317
item.dc:creator: @sinisoul sini
item.description:
@sinisoul wrote:

LilXCj:

I hate it when you develop something, find out there’s a better alternative, only to realize that your hours of work probably meant nothing.

But that is part of the learning process.

October 20 -

I am going to keep this short and simple because I wrote a full page and at the last second Netbeans decided to fuck me over, and while I was trying to take a screen-shot of the splash screen decided that it was just going to take my mouse hostage and lock me out. So here are script files, if you understand them great if you don’t sorry I just don’t feel like explaining again.

--[[ bindtoolkit.lua
    	Written by Hadyn Fitzgerald
]]

--Check if the toolkit has been bound
if toolkit ~= nil then
	return
end

--Bind the toolkit
toolkit = luajava.bindClass("java.awt.Toolkit")
--[[ buildsplash.lua
    	Written by Hadyn Fitzgerald
]]

--Bind the splashscrn
dofile("./bin/scripts/bind/bindsplash.lua")

--Bind the alphacomp
dofile("./bin/scripts/bind/bindalphacomp.lua")

--Bind the color
dofile("./bin/scripts/bind/bindcolor.lua")

--Create the screen
local screen = splashscrn:getSplashScreen()

--Create the graphics
local graphics = screen:createGraphics()

--Create the base splash table
local Splash = { }

--Create splash table method
Splash.new = function(g, s) 

    --The to be created table
    local t = { }
    
    --Local variables
    g = graphics or nil
    s = screen or nil
    
    --The draw function for the table
    t.draw = function() 
        g:setColor(color.BLACK)
        g:fillRect(120,140,200,40)
    end
    
    --Update function for the table
    t.update = function()
    	t.draw()
    	s:update()
    end
    
    return t
end


--Create the splash table
splash = Splash.new(graphics, screen)

while 1 do
	splash.update()
end

Brb making sure this doesn’t happen again.

Well it did, ill figure it out tomorrow. Night everyone.

Read full topic

item.title: CodeUSA - 317
item.dc:creator: @Codeusa12 Codeusa12
item.description:
@Codeusa12 wrote:

[quote=“sinisoul, post:48, topic:418466”][quote author=Davidi2 link=topic=521009.msg3788383#msg3788383 date=1319074577]
Apparently the mod that moderated her minds it (Wasn’t me…)
[/quote]

Right…well maybe that moderator should relax a bit (Well at least on this thread )

ANYWAY,

October 19 -

How many of you are fans of Led Zeppelin? I am not sure why but I really do love some of the remixes of their songs (although I note they are never as good as the originals), they make me feel a bit more reborn. Today was very slow day but it was fairly productive. I browsed around Fusion trying to home in on some unnecessary methods or terrible designs that I had made a month or two back and realized that I forgot to finish the floor definition. A bit of clickity clacking later, finished writing for floor definitions. From previous days I have come to the conclusion that the amount of effort and time it takes me to hard code every god damn operation code into a parsing and writing method, I could easily come up with a better solution that speeds up the process and pushes for some more more ‘advanced’ features. After I finished floors I transitioned into installing Lua on my linux computer. FOUR HOURS LATER, I figure out that there is a download that automatically configures the entire download for me. From that point it only took me 5 minutes to get the binaries and jar for the LuaJava set up, which was the only thing I really needed. For the rest of my time developing I began to make diagrams of how I thought the plugin and component system of Cosmos would take shape to look like. I believe I have a reasonable design but since it is still on the drawing board, I will hold off on explaining it just yet. I am looking forward to developing the GUI because it will be pushing my boundaries as a programmer, trying to integrate Lua and java to form a fast reliable product.

http://pastie.org/2727833

In the next coming weeks me and Andrew have discussed the possibility of selling a couple of the products we produced but that is still a bit sketchy on if that is allowed on some forums/how we would do that. Just letting you know now, it isn’t going to be cheap.

Well I guess that is all for tonight everyone, stay tuned for what happens tomorrow :)[/quote]

Good job love.

Read full topic

How many of you are fans of Led Zeppelin? I am not sure why but I really do love some of the remixes of their songs (although I note they are never as good as the originals), they make me feel a bit more reborn. Today was very slow day but it was fairly productive. I browsed around Fusion trying to home in on some unnecessary methods or terrible designs that I had made a month or two back and realized that I forgot to finish the floor definition. From previous days I have come to the conclusion that the amount of effort and time it takes me to hard code every god damn operation code into a parsing and writing method, I could easily come up with a better solution that speeds up the process and pushes for some more more ‘advanced’ features. After I finished floors I transitioned into installing Lua on my linux computer. FOUR HOURS LATER, I figure out that there is a download that automatically configures the entire download for me. From that point it only took me 5 minutes to get the binaries and jar for the LuaJava set up, which was the only thing I really needed. For the rest of my time developing I began to make diagrams of how I thought the plugin and component system of Cosmos would take shape to look like. I believe I have a reasonable design but since it is still on the drawing board, I will hold off on explaining it just yet. I am looking forward to developing the GUI because it will be pushing my boundaries as a programmer, trying to integrate Lua and java to form a fast reliable product.

http://pastie.org/2727833

In the next coming weeks me and Andrew have discussed the possibility of selling a couple of the products we produced but that is still a bit sketchy on if that is allowed on some forums/how we would do that. Just letting you know now, it isn’t going to be cheap.

Well I guess that is all for tonight everyone, stay tuned for what happens tomorrow

item.title: CodeUSA - 317
item.dc:creator: @sinisoul sini
item.description:
@sinisoul wrote:

October 18 -

Today was a fairly productive day, me and Dawn decided to move forward with our secret project although because of political reasons I will not be starting to assist her with the project until I finish this project and hand it over to my content team. I find it a bit amusing it took us 5 hours to think of a name and the name wasn’t really that original, since it was kinda reborn from some ideas floating around in her head. From the time I sat down at my desk to now I have been working ever so hard on NPC definitions so that I can get them the hell out of the way. The amount of data is just so…boring to write a parsing and writing method that I occasionally smash my head on my desk. I would love to know more about how the lighting system worked in conjunction with writing some functions for finding the intensity of light at a point in a triangle. But like other things mentioned before, that will have to wait. I also took an initiative to rewrite my DirectIndexSprite class to get an idea of the naming conventions and what not:

http://pastie.org/2721873

Removing the dummies is fairly annoying so after I found all the raster methods I had just given up and sloppily went through and punched names to all the variables. Haha, lazy programming gets to me yet again! Another thing I rewrote today was the method determining if hidden text should be shown or not be shown. It was interesting to say the least! And I must say that I can see some good future implications with all the operations that it allows me to do, especially in the case of say the player walking to a certain tile (Quests and what not). I really hate the way they work with the variable protocol so I might just add my own type of scripting system like the calculation system I studied. Well I guess that is all for now, have a great night.

Read full topic
